articles.headline: Racial Bias Skewed Small-Business Relief Lending, Study Says
articles.snippet: Black business owners were more likely to get Paycheck Protection Program loans from online lenders than from banks, according to new research.
articles.abstract: Black business owners were more likely to get Paycheck Protection Program loans from online lenders than from banks, according to new research.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the very start of the Paycheck Protection Program last year, it was clear that minority entrepreneurs, especially Black business owners, struggled more than white borrowers to find a willing lender. A new research project indicates that the problem was particularly pronounced at smaller banks — and human bias appears to be the main reason.

articles.headline: Loans Will Be the Key to Banks’ Future Fortunes
articles.snippet: The big banks are expected to benefit from increased consumer spending when they report earnings this week. Where they go from here will depend greatly on lending to households and businesses.
articles.abstract: The big banks are expected to benefit from increased consumer spending when they report earnings this week. Where they go from here will depend greatly on lending to households and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: As investors brace for underwhelming earnings reports across much of the business world, the country’s biggest banks are expected to report solid profits this week, thanks to the central role they play in the reopening economy.

articles.headline: Biden’s Proposal to Empower I.R.S. Rattles Banks and Their Customers
articles.snippet: To help fund its new initiatives, the Biden administration wants banks to report more customer information. Account holders aren’t happy.
articles.abstract: To help fund its new initiatives, the Biden administration wants banks to report more customer information. Account holders aren’t happy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Biden administration looked for ways to pay for the president’s expansive social policy bill, it proposed raising revenue by cracking down on $7 trillion in unpaid taxes, mostly from wealthy Americans and businesses.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: A Babysitter and a Band-Aid Wrapper: Inside the Submarine Spy Case
articles.snippet: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe seemed like an ordinary suburban couple, but the F.B.I. said they were would-be spies — and sloppy ones.
articles.abstract: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe seemed like an ordinary suburban couple, but the F.B.I. said they were would-be spies — and sloppy ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On July 28, Diana Toebbe posted a Facebook message looking for a babysitter to take care of her children early on the coming Saturday morning for five to six hours.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Brenda Wintrode and JoAnna Daemmrich

articles.headline: In China, Home Buyers Who Went All In Say They Want Out
articles.snippet: China Evergrande Group’s financial troubles, and the government policies that helped push it to the brink of collapse, have threatened an important economic driver: home sales.
articles.abstract: China Evergrande Group’s financial troubles, and the government policies that helped push it to the brink of collapse, have threatened an important economic driver: home sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: China is trying to cool its costly and dangerously debt-ridden housing market, where high prices and go-go levels of borrowing and spending are increasingly seen as a national threat.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong

articles.headline: As Bike Thefts Jump, Delivery Workers Band Together for Safety
articles.snippet: Robbers are targeting food delivery workers in New York City, so many are forming watch groups to protect one another.
articles.abstract: Robbers are targeting food delivery workers in New York City, so many are forming watch groups to protect one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven nights a week, starting around 9:30, Vicente Carrasco cheers and whistles at food delivery workers as they ride their bicycles into Manhattan after crossing the Queensboro Bridge. The message he’s sending? “Someone’s looking out for you.”

articles.headline: The Body Collector of Spain: When Migrants Die at Sea, He Gets Them Home
articles.snippet: Martín Zamora, the owner of a funeral parlor near Gibraltar, has found an unusual line of business among the relatives of those who drown trying to reach Europe.
articles.abstract: Martín Zamora, the owner of a funeral parlor near Gibraltar, has found an unusual line of business among the relatives of those who drown trying to reach Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGECIRAS, Spain — No one knew the man’s name when he washed ashore. His body had floated in the ocean for weeks, and it then sat much of the summer unidentified in a refrigerator in a Spanish morgue.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Leire Ariz Sarasketa
